table: Vini Lopez I was in "Sonny and the Starfires" and we were set up right next to the Castiles. Over 20 bands were there. The Rogues were 1st, Sonny and the Starfires were 2nd, I can't remember who finished 3rd. We all thought that it was between us and the Castiles. They didn't come in the top 3.

Mark Flanagan Pine Brook Middle School. Manalapan. The original band canceled. Tex Vineyard was called and the Castile came. The band played three sets. Bruce sang during the third set. Also, they won the battle of the bands at Gordon's Corner Elementary school earlier that summer. The band form Yorktowne Drive, The Living End with Frankie Noviello lost.

© Jeannie Clark Fisher The first time I remember really setting eyes on Bruce Springsteen was at the Off Broad Street Coffee House, where I sang often in the late 1960s and early "70s. I knew he had a high school band, The Castiles, that rivaled my band from Middletown, the Gross National Product. He appeared shy, alone, and mysterious. His hair was long, or seemed long to a girl fresh out of high school in the 60s. I hadn't seen hair like that on a guy, except for Bob Dylan's bass player, when I saw him perform at Rutgers University. I didn't have the courage to walk up and talk to Bruce, although I sensed that he had a soul deeper than the GI I was hanging with, sitting with a group around a table.

Vini Lopez This is where I asked Bruce to jam at the Upstage. Soon after we got together.

Lynwood Franklin I played in a band called The Morning Disaster and I'm pretty sure we opened for Child on the 19th and 20th. At the time I was playing a Danelectro Longhorn Bass and at the sound check Bruce and I had a conversation about it. He said that Danelctros were made in Neptune City, just down the road from where they lived. We agreed that, though they were inexpensive, they played and sounded good. This was the first time I saw him play and it was clear that he had a stage presence that was exceptional. I saw him a few weeks later backstage when he played at the VCU gym. He told me a funny story . He said he had been surfing at the Jersey shore and his surfboard came up and hit him in the mouth and broke his front tooth. He didn't want to go on stage looking like that so he went to a dentist to get it fixed. He had to fill out some paperwork and when he put 'musician' as his occupation they said the fee would be $200, in advance. So he had to deplete his savings but he got his tooth fixed. We were supposed to open for them again that November but our keyboard player got sick and we had to cancel. He was, and still is I'm sure, a nice fellow, very approachable, a mensch.

Kevin Gray Although not famous like Springsteen, Mike (Mike McAdam, who was Steve Earle's guitarist around the Guitar Town tour.) introduced me to Bruce on a March 1970 evening, when his band The Emotions had opened for Steel Mill, fronted by Springsteen, at Richmond, Virginia’s, Hullabaloo Club, a no-alcohol teen club. That evening Bruce introduced Steven Van Zandt, a new member of the band. Little Stevie was playing a very cool looking plexiglass bass. Bruce thanked me for being there, shook my hand with a soft and sincere grip, and continued to hang with Mike and me. Mike and I were just high school juniors.

Jerome G. Snider It was a Brick Township prom. There was a band, the Gordon James Quintet, and Bruce playing solo. It was not two shows, but continuous music where our band played dance music and then Bruce performed with an acoustic guitar and harmonica on a neck holder, and then back and forth throughout the evening.
Richard Sette It was the Brick High School Junior Prom. The band was The Gordon James Quintet. (Gordon is now a Jazz artist. This was his first band) this ban played for the dance and Springsteen played solo during dinner. I can swear to the accuracy of this account as I know several people who were there. I was the lead singer in the GJQ. My future wife was an attendee and was involved in booking Bruce.
Rose Marie Leeds (D’Elia) Class of 1971 In early 1970 Bruce Springsteen did, in fact, play an acoustic guitar on stage at the Regency-Irvington Hotel in Lakewood, NJ. Here, the Brick Township High School Junior Prom was held, class of 1971. He played his guitar and sang as we ate dinner. It was not a concert probably less than an hour.

@ Jeannie Clark Fisher I was doing my set on a small stage away from the main concert. Steve, Garry, and Johnny (Funky Dusty & The Soul Broom) were backing me up. I was wearing a mink wrap with heads and tails still attached that my crazy Uncle Lenny gave me. The wrap really grossed-out my friends, Rob and Paul, but I thought it was a very Janis Joplin thing to wear. She also had a great influence on my singing style then. That was one of the best times, musically, that I remember.

Jerry Tirotta ’71 I saw many great shows at Monmouth—Jethro Tull, The Byrds, John Mayal—but my favorite was the first time I saw Bruce. It was 1969 or ’70, and I was sick in bed with the flu. My roommates said, “Come on, we’re going to see Steel Mill.” Steel who? When we got there, the gym was sectioned off in half. In front of us was a minimal drum kit, a bass guitar, a guitar, and a few small amps. I said, “I got out of bed for this?” Bruce came out and the band started to play … and play … and play—three hours of original material, and the place was going wild. Just phenomenal! I walked out into the night and had an epiphany: I was cured.

© Jeannie Clark Fisher I rode down to the gig in Tinker’s truck. We stopped at a gas station and I bought a packaged cupcake with cinnamon crumb topping. Tinker made me look at the ingredients and he gave me a lecture about all the chemical junk it had in it. He seemed very ahead of his time to me with his California awareness of nutritional issues. I opened the show for Steel Mill at the University of Richmond standing on one end of the gymnasium, playing my guitar and singing to a crowd of students, all sitting on the floor. The music went well, but I was starting to get the sense that the lone, folk troubadour was not going to have as vast an audience as it had in the ‘60s. The times were changing again.

© Jeannie Clark Fisher I played The Upstage the night after this show. The Upstage Coffeehouse was a great place – small and intimate with a listening crowd. I remember climbing the stairway that led to the tiny backstage area. The stage itself was compact, but didn't discourage the musicians on hand to jam at times on my solo sets – Bruce, Garry Tallent, Vini Lopez, Steven Van Zandt, "Southside" Johnny Lyon, and my good friend, the late clarinet/sax player, Terry Loughran. I sang and banged on the old, out-of -tune upright piano or strummed my Martin guitar, while Tinker taped the music onto his reel-to-reel recorder. (I still have the original tape of the show on January 24th. The band, "Odin", with their lengthy, spacey, instrumental, acid-rock music, played that night, also.)
Songs: "Feel Like A Woman", "Back Here", "Livin' In The Country", "You Ain't Goin' Nowhere", "The World's A Sad Place", "Black Skies", "No One's Lesson But Your Own".

Alan Bloom I was at these shows. Bruce definitely introduced the band from the stage as Dr Zoom and the Sonic Boom. I can remember the exact way he said it. It was like “We’re Dr, ZOOOOOM and the Sonic Boom”, emphasis on Zoom. Also, the show was so sparsely attended that the venue encouraged everyone in the first set to stay for the second set. Of course, we did!

Of course, we did!

© Jeannie Clark Fisher I was a "Zoomette" for two gigs with "Dr. Zoom and the Sonic Boom", Bruce's interim band. It was a fun and joyous, somewhat organized, free-for-all! My memory of the Sunshine Inn was a large, rectangular room with concrete floors and square support pillars and a free-standing stage to one side. There was standing room only and lots of people dancing. The next day we went out to Newark for an outside performance. I still have the short, butterfly, hippie dress I wore that day and I bring it out occasionally for Gross National Product, my high school band, reunion concerts.

© Jeannie Clark Fisher This was the second annual "Nothing's Festival", although the first annual one, scheduled at the Beachcomber in Long Branch, NJ, didn't happen for some reason. A brainchild of Carl "Tinker" West, the event was truly in the flower-people spirit; nobody got paid and no one paid to come. It was a warm, summer afternoon. My father tuned the piano and he also tuned for Bruce on several other occasions. Bruce Springsteen's Band was the headliner. I did my solo set and bands, Sunny Jim and Odin filled in the middle spots. My friend, Geoff, said to me as Bruce was playing, "this guy is going to be really big someday".
My songs: "You Ain't Goin' Nowhere" (Bob Dylan cover), "Back Here", "Feel Like A Woman".

© Jeannie Clark Fisher Tinker set up a solo concert for me in the summer of 1971. I don't remember the exact date. The outdoor concert was in a park not far from the ocean and the Long Branch boardwalk. I remember seeing Bruce in the audience, appearing very interested as I sang my song 'It Really Doesn't Matter'. After I finished Bruce jumped up on stage, followed by Vini Lopez, Garry Tallent and the usual crowd of New Jersey musicians, to jam the rest of the night away.
Steve DeVito I was at that concert, I was 7 and my friend Mitch had an older brother Miles, known as Rabbit. He played in the opening band.

Mark Prellberg Monday, March 27, 1972 is the date that I saw the Bruce Springsteen Band at the Back Door with approx. 9 other patrons. Of course I couldn't provide any kind of set list because at that time I had never heard any of his music. In fact, I was totally unaware of him until the fall of 1971. I was a college student at a small school in Kansas and I met a fellow longhair (Kevin Gray) from Richmond who spent 6 months raving about how great Bruce was. Of course I thought Kevin was full of s**t, Bruce's name was completely unknown in my part of the world (and remained that way until Greetings… was released). No way anybody that under-the-radar could be as incredible as Kevin claimed, so that's why we hitched back to his hometown on spring break, even though we didn't know whether or not he'd be playing while we were there. The gods smiled on us, fortunately… The only cover song they performed that I recognized was "Not Fade Away", a Stones-like version, if memory serves. And, yeah, the BSB lived up to Kevin's non-stop hype, I've always let him know how forever indebted I am for giving me the 'advance notice.' I 'm pretty certain my does not have anything from that specific show. He usually carried his camera everywhere but for some unknown reason he didn't have it with him that night. The reason he was able to pinpoint the date was because the day after that we went up to Maryland and saw the Beach Boys at the University of Maryland, and that date is documented on a Beach Boys concert website. I knew we had seen Bruce before the Beach Boys show, I just didn't remember it being one day before, although I did know for certain that the Back Door performance was NOT on the weekend. It Wasn't until the Born To Run tour in '75 that I got to see him live again, and he crawled off the stage and into my lap during the breakdown part of Spirit In The Night, so that made the 2nd 'never will forget' Springsteen memory in my lifetime.

Victor 'Igor' Wasylczenko
Promoter		 I attended one of these Van Ronk dates, Bruce was definitely the opener, and I ended up giving him a ride home to Asbury Park after the show (we lived near each other at the time).

Michael Hommel We rehearsed at Tinker’s factory for a few years around that time. So yes, I was a member of Odin for the National Guard show as well as the Huddy Park show. Later Odin changed its name to The Proof. We were the opening act for Bruce for the grand opening of Big Man’s West. It was so brutally hot that night and the AC didn’t work. Agh!!!

Michael Hommel We rehearsed at Tinker’s factory for a few years around that time. So yes, I was a member of Odin for the National Guard show as well as the Huddy Park show. Later Odin changed its name to The Proof. We were the opening act for Bruce for the grand opening of Big Man’s West. It was so brutally hot that night and the AC didn’t work. Agh!!!

Richard Clark My roommates and I were juniors at York College living in a apartment on Beaver St. I was part of the basketball team a very short time before a season ending injury so we were all basketball player’s and fans. That night on Saturday, November 11, 1972 we headed back to campus, where the action was. We had a choice of a free concert or take in a basketball game. We decided to check out the concert thinking that’s where most of the campus crowd would be. To our surprise, the concert was all but empty, with students preferring to attend the basketball game, rather than attending the concert of a relatively unknown rocker. So after a song or two, we also headed to the game, unknown to us that we had the opportunity to attend the concert of a future legend. The story I enjoy telling about seeing Springsteen was I once saw him for free and didn’t stay for the whole performance. Thanks for letting me share this unbelievable memory.

Peter Cunningham Bruce invited me to come down to see a rehearsal in Red Bank, NJ before the band's first public gig at The Main Point outside of Philadelphia upon release of the album. The rehearsal was striking for how much respect the band members showed to Bruce, he didn't demand it at all, he was loose and relaxed, but he was completely in charge.

Fritz Roth In 1973 I was working for a record one-stop on Long Island. Bruce was opening for the Paul Winter Consort for 4 nights. Paul Winter had just released his one and only album on Columbia Records Epic label and of course Greetings had just come out. I had seen the album and assumed from the lyrics on the back and continued on the inside that Bruce was a folkie. Columbia was very interested in having a full house there and had put several of us from the one-stop on the guest list for the Saturday shows. I was a big Paul Winter fan at the time and arrived in time for his first set. Bruce's second set was a revelation. I never bought another Paul Winter album. The best musicians in his band had left and formed the group Oregon, who I saw many times over the years. I've been a fan of Bruce's for over 50 years now.

B. Hassett The ticket was $1.00 and about 150 - 200 kids showed up but the band played like there were 10,000. Bruce was wearing a newsboy cap and he was all over the place. Thin, full beard, leather jacket and a tee shirt. He exploded right in front of us. I had never seen anything like him or the band. I think they played about three hours. I was physically exhausted and can only imagine how Bruce and the Band felt. I remember some of their early songs and I also remember "Devil With The Blue Dress On". I think they played "Come Together" by the Beatles too. When it was over, we were exhausted. I went to breakfast late that night at a diner and there they were. I said hello, told them how great the show was and made small talk. Bruce could not have been nicer. Clarence too. A few months later they came back to NU and there were probably 1000 people there.

Kevin L. Hanlon Bruce got to providence very late…’announcement that bus was held up’… This was part of ‘Providence College Spring Weekend’ so many people attended on-campus concert not knowing anything about the artist. Place was at less than a hundred people by the time he came on… Bruce opened with Billy's wild circus and the crowd was sort of looking at each other wondering what this was all about? Within a couple of songs, he sat at piano and performed ‘spirit in the night’. Electric guitar for growing up. And he was off and running…

Loren Bruce came to Waynesburg at the request of a friend who's name I have forgotten. Our normal opening act had a gig in Pittsburgh so Bruce and the E Street Band did the opening act. For Jim Stafford "Spiders and Snakes". Everyone was blown away at how fabulous this act was. They opened with New York City Serenade and went straight through for 90 minutes. Jim Stafford took the stage, told everyone that they would probably never see anything like that ever again. He said he was contracted to sing his 'Spiders and Snakes' song and that he would leave after that so as not to spoil what we had all experienced. In that 90 minutes Springsteen had synthesized the preceding quarter of century of rock and roll.

Tom Gillen I attended both the shows at Oliver’s (now k/a Cask N Flagon on 10/18 & 10/19. I was a student at Boston University and one of my dorm mates at Myles Standish Hall – Bob Himlefrarb talked a bunch of us into going to the first performance. Bob was from Holmdel New Jersey and said he had seen him in the Asbury Park area – and said he was with a band – I think the name of the band he said had the name of “Steel…”. We had plenty to drink & we were outgoing and with a smallish crowd we were able to converse with Bruce between songs. We let him know Bob was from NJ and I was from Philly. I asked him if he could play Tommy from the Who. He smiled and played a bunch of songs from the famous album – duplicating the music perfectly.
We went back the next night – crowd swelled to about 40-50 then, ha. We re-introduced ourselves. He was incredibly polite. He told all of us that he just signed on with Columbia records, I believe.
In the spring I went to Philly during semester break and asked my girlfriend who was a student (Eva Georgias) if she wanted to hear this cool band play – at the Main Point. She agreed, we had a great time – much bigger crowd by then over 100 people.

George Rothe I was at the early show at Max’s with a friend and sat at a table front center under Bruce’s mic. I am pretty sure it was a Friday, thus chose this date. Hall and Oates opened and were greeted by my friend yelling at them to ‘GET OFF!’ and ‘WE WANT BRUCE!’. They played for about 45 minutes (as you noted on the website), featuring songs from Abandoned Luncheonette. All the while, my friend yelling up at them at the end of each song. Embarrassing, or what! Their keyboardist played what seemed to be a mellotron. I wasn’t too impressed.
I think Bruce may have opened with ‘Sandy’ with Danny on a chair, center stage, playing accordion while Bruce sang and played acoustic. Or, it could have been later in the show. Not sure. The band took the stage. Clarence wore a hot pink outfit with matching cap. Bruce was in his traditional black turtleneck sweater and grey tweed newsboy cap. I remember Albany Al coming on stage to join the band for E Street Shuffle, I guess. Bruce told a story about signing with Colombia. ‘Everything was white and gold’ as he took the elevator up to the Columbia offices. I don’t remember what song followed. I do remember David strumming the piano strings for Serenade, like on the album. My friend kept calling out for ‘Thundercrack’ (he was hard to miss sitting right under Bruce). He had heard the song at MSG that summer and kept raving to me about it. I am pretty sure they played it. At one point Bruce broke his pick and asked if anyone in the audience had an extra. I had one in my back pocket and handed it up to him. ‘Nah, too big’, as he handed it back to me. Of course, I held onto it all these years! (see Memorabilia-tab). Bruce dedicated ‘For You’ (slow, piano version) to Dave Gahr who was in the audience that night. The same night I was converted!

Pete Stoffee I believe the opening act was a cover band called Dick van and the Dykes. We danced crazy to Bruce and as the loud whistler at the end of the show I got to thank Bruce and shake his hand before heading back across the bay to Fall River. Clearly the best show in my long life of shows. The cops tried to stop it because of some curfew but Bruce and the band wouldn't have it.
Steven R. Silvia I worked at the Motor Lodge as a busboy/server in prior years. The stage was low, approx. 18” off the floor. The ballroom had partitions to divide it into three private events but partitions were collapsed, making for one large room. If I recall correctly, there were no seats. Attendees either sat on the floor or stood. Bruce and the band arrived late. Hence, the Bristol Police Dept. enforced the town curfew, making for the 100 minute show.
Bruce and the band arrived early but their equipment manager quit, they had to find another. (apparently this new guy was Butch). The concert coordinator for Roger Williams College received a call from Butch saying he was on the Tappen Zee bridge in NY at 6:25pm with a flat tire. Another band opened the show at 9. After a very long wait and with no explanations at all to the crowd (less than 100 people) Bruce, apologizing for a bunch of mess ups, finally took the stage at 12:35am. He played Walking The Dog (cover of the Rufus Thomas song), Kitty’s Back and Rosalita. He stretched out each song because he and the band were informed the town curfew was 1am (the show was a lot shorter than a previously reported 100 minutes. Just after 1am the power to the room was cut off, bringing the show to a close). It is uncertain whether or not Bruce & the band did get to play Santa Claus Is Coming to Town.
(The above is courtesy of me as an eyewitness part of the evening and the entertainment writer for The New Paper (writing this evening for RWC’s campus paper).

David Cannon The Joint in the Woods didn't have tickets for Springsteen shows. In fact, the January show and the April 13, 1974 shows only had about a dozen people in the audience. (Mad Dog Lopez actually staggered past me muttering, "This band is going nowhere.") For comparison, I couldn't get in to the Strawbs performance 2/15/74 it was so crowded.

Michael Platton I was there on that cold February evening. And there was only like 30 people there in the audience and the boss gets on the stage and says that he feels like he’s running a really high fever or has the flu and then proceeds to blow the house out with Rosalita and did all of the ‘The wild the innocent …’as if he was just fine and wasn’t sick at all. Even to this day I can remember the excitement that I had watching him on stage like 3 feet away gyrating next to Clarence And never having seen anything like that since Elvis. His sad version on ‘Billy’ made the crowd silent - everyone there was wondering if the next Bob Dylan had been witnessed.

Rick Bohs I did attend this show. My brother was a student at WIDENER and he gave me 2 tickets that afternoon when I ran into him at my mother’s house. I had gotten married and my wife did not want to go so I went solo. My most memorable moment came at the encore when Bruce, by himself, sat at the piano and sung “For You”. I was no more that 5 feet from the side stage and saw him do it.
Scott McConnell For what it's worth, I used to work with a guy who went to this show and he told me that on "Bus Stop…82nd St." when Springsteen got to the line "Uptown in Harlem she throws a rose," someone in the audience threw a rose and Springsteen caught it. For what it's worth…

David Cannon I have a diary note from 4/13/1974 that Bruce played at Joint in the Woods with Buzzy Linhart and Bruce’s band was “too loud.” I had seen him previously at the Joint on 1/12/1974 and at Max’s Kansas City 2/3/1973 and 11/10/1973 so I was disappointed by the painful volume level. The Joint in the Woods didn’t have tickets for Springsteen shows. In fact, the January show and the April 13, 1974 shows only had about a dozen people in the audience.

Andrew V. Shawn ’74 I was in a Blues-oriented group, The Charlie Smith Band, while at Monmouth. We opened for B.B. King when he played Monmouth Gym in 1971. We had opened for him once before, in Albany, New York, in 1969. B.B. remembered us and was very gracious, and we all had a great time together that evening. By May 1974, I was in another band, Clockwork, and we opened for Bruce Springsteen on campus. It was a packed house in the gym, and I was very proud when the announcer said, “Here is Clockwork, featuring our own Andy Shawn.” Bruce and the band were also very gracious.

WillyJ I was there and remember clearly: Bruce was introducing and was about to play Rosalita. Someone from the crowd screams out MOUNTAIN!. Mountain was the headliner that evening. And Bruce says – “Rosie will make a mountain out of you!”.

Fred Cohen I was an active member of Fairleigh Dickinson University and a member of the concert committee. Having been lucky enough to have seen Bruce at the first concert I went to at the Spectrum when opened up for Chicago and was hooked. I saw him play all night at the Erlton Lounge in Cherry Hill where I'm from. Subsequently I provided security, if you could call it that, at Widener College and State Theater. Many of my friends still talk about me high jacking them to the Stone Pony for many amazing shows. But I digress.
He did play FDU. I remember the bill and I lobbied hard as many people didn't know him yet. It was a cold day and I remember running around with my friend Jane trying to get to students out. I mean it was a free show. How could you not see it. Though I do not remember the set list. I have been to so many shows, been backstage and had the good fortune to have hung will Clarence and Danny. I can tell you there were only a couple hundred people present give or take.

John Carpenter I bought tickets to this show, trust me I remember it well. I took my ex-girlfriend and was going to impress her with Springsteen. He was supposed to play on a bill with Maria Muldaur and Danny O'Keefe. The Civic Center staff made a brief announcement at the start of the show that Bruce was not available to play. For years I heard rumors that he had gotten sick eating a bad hot dog outside the Civic Center. The Guess Who had played in OKC earlier that year, I am confident because I went to that one also. Ex-girl friend was not impressed with Maria and Danny but the good news is Bruce came back to OKC Civic Center in 75 and I had a front row center seat for the Born to Run tour!

Stuart Churchill

The subject of Bruce in Central Park came up and I thought I would share my memories of the night. Please bear in mind that all I had to go on was the Cover of Wild & Innocent. So I was unsure of who was in the band until others confirmed the dates of the band change. Also, as background, I was in NYC for my father's second wedding, so you might imagine there was a fair amount of confusion and emotional storms going on. Leaving that aside, I arrived a couple of days before the show (Rehearsal dinner, etc.). I saw in the paper that Bruce was playing Central Park. My younger sister Catherine who was also attending also wanted to go. This is the main reason I hadn't brought a tape recorder. As it was I remember a fair amount of security so it wouldn't have worked anyway. So after putting in an appearance at the wedding reception, My sister and I made our inconspicuous exit. I think we walked to the park, where there was a long line to get in. I barely remember Brewer & Shipley, but I was riveted once Bruce came on. I didn't keep a setlist during the show, but did write one down from memory when I got back to Michigan. I can't promise it's completely accurate, but there's more than is currently in BruceBase.

INCIDENT ON 52nd STREET / SPIRIT IN THE NIGHT /DOES THIS BUS STOP AT 82nd / IT'S HARD TO BE A SAINT IN THE CITY / JUNGLELAND / KITTY'S BACK / ROSALITA (COME OUT TONIGHT).

Performance notes: Incident started very softly with David Sancious playing the intro. Bruce came on and did what I can only call an interpretive dance acting out the various parts and actions in the song. The other band members came in one-by-one (including Suki Lahav, I think) until it ended at full volume. Jungleland was of course a new song, and the version he did had the "Hungry and Hunted" portion of the song as a repeated chorus, which I noted in my setlist. I think a version from the Bottom Line also had this version. He dedicated "Kitty's Back" to a topless dancer and the Sportsmans Club in NJ (Bruce does love his topless dancers). One of the things that divided my attention was watching my younger sister. So when he started "Rosalita" everyone stood and rushed the stage. I wanted to but didn't want to lose track of my sister. When I looked for her she was way ahead of me crowding the stage. I was worried about staying out too late and possibly missing connections with my father, So I decided to leave after Springsteen's set with the slight worry about walking through Central Park after dark. However it soon became clear that nearly everyone was leaving so there was safety in the crowd from my NYC paranoia. Anyway when I got back home I wrote down a list of the songs I remembered him doing. So I may have missed a song or two or gotten one wrong.
Brucebace Reader It is absolutely true that most of the crowd booed when the announcer informed us that Anne Murray would be out in fifteen minutes, while we were still screaming for another encore. Most of us left. In Los Angeles, Marc Brickman (Bruce's lighting director) was talking to my wife and said that Anne Murray was hysterical backstage, really pissed off that her manager had forced Bruce to play second. The story made it to John Sebastian, who voluntarily took second spot (in a triple-billing) on October 18 in Passaic.
Brucebace Reader I remembers that the vast majority left after Springsteen, leaving only around a quarter of the original audience for Murray.

Rick Bohs I worked for the promoter and was backstage for this show. Another great one, but I have no memory of the setlist, but he did reprise the piano solo on “For You” that I saw a few moths back at Widener.

Jeffrey Meissner I was at the show along with 900 plus students. This was my 2nd show and I knew what to expect. It was two days before Bruce's Birthday and a young woman in a red bikini brought out a cake filled with sparklers. I have several pictures of Bruce and one of Clarence from that show. It was a great show and it seemed like he wanted all of the people who didn't buy tickets for the gym to know they missed something special. I don't remember the set list except for a searing hot performance of Mona into She's the One. Playing along with Bruce was Suki Lahav to his left looking at the stage for the 1st time. Pictures were credited to Marc Bittan who was a staff photographer for the State Times. Don't know if he was related to Roy.
Robert Dwyer I was at this show. I was freshman at Oneonta State. I've told this story a million times. It was one of those life changing events. I had never heard of Springsteen. After the first act my friends and myself were like if this guy sucks we're leaving and going downtown bar hopping. Bruce came on and sang "Incident on 57 street" archipelago for the first few minutes, just him, with one spot light on him. Man it was powerful. They Rocked! I remember a few of the songs that they played "E street", "Sandy", "New York Serenade" (was incredible, with I found out later, David Sancious) and "Rosilita". I know he played some from Asbury Park but it's a bit more iffy, "Growin Up". Anyway next day I bought "Wild, Innocent & E Street Shuffle", And "Greetings from Asbury Park". There was no "Born To Run" yet. I was hooked and spread the news far and wide. told my friends at upstate colleges to catch him. Became the piped piper of Bruce. Got all my friends to love him too.
Frank Wesley In 1974 I’d never heard of the guy but my dorm room friends got me to go (we were across the street at Hartwick College). Cost 2 dollars to get in. He was billed as a Dylan impersonator in the school paper. One of my friends was excited and had seen him playing in a small bar a year or so before. We went over earlier before the show and walked backstage and talk to Bruce for what seemed like hours. I remember thinking, wow, this is the nicest guy but he really can’t grow a beard! Pretty scruffy looking for a performer. Later when the show started and we had seats up close to the front, Bruce came out and dedicated a song to “Bushman” (that was the nickname of my friend Jeff Bosch). Quite an electrifying performance and one I’ll never forget. The show was in one of the smaller theaters on campus and it seemed like half the seats were empty!

JerseyJoe My Most Memorable Show! On September 22, 1974 I attended my very first Bruce concert. It was a free outdoor concert at Kean College in Union, New Jersey. It was a good show but not great. A month later I saw Bruce on October 18, 1974 at The Capitol Theater in Passaic, New Jersey (as a bus trip sponsored by a local college). There were 3 acts on the bill. They were Dan Fogelberg, Bruce & headliner John Sebastian (of The Lovin Spoonful fame). Years later I confirmed the rumored story with John Sebastian himself that he heard Bruce's rehearsal and said there was no way that he was going to follow Bruce on stage; so Bruce closed the show. It was by far the most intense concert I have ever seen in my life. The mixture of Bruce's voice and Suki Lahav's violin playing were magical. Hearing new material from what would become an lp called "Born to Run" was also a treat. This new song called "Jungleland" was especially moving and powerful and unlike any other Bruce song. I was a fairly reserved person back then but I remember dancing in the aisle with a few thousand of my closest friends. It was much more than a concert for sure.

Eddie Ruppert The show was scheduled for September 28. Bruce Springsteen was a no-show he was drunk apparently. Everyone was given the option of a refund or to watch the good rats perform. My date and I decided to watch the good rats, awesome show. Honestly I never looked at Springsteen with the same eyes again.

Brucebase Reader My wife and I were in front of the stage during "Quarter To Three" when the first two rows of seats next to us just disappeared, the left side of the stage and first couple of rows fell about six feet. A couple of monitors fell in where the people were seated but it didn't appear that anyone got hurt. The encore was abruptly ended however.
Joe Kivak
(via Facebook)		 At the end of "Quarter To Three" the front of the stage collapsed, And that was the end of the show. On the recording you can hear the announcement, "Please move back to the front of the auditorium. Please move back!".
O, I left and missed it (in response to Art Reilly's remark on not recording "On Broadway").
Art Reilly
(via Facebook)		 I was stage right, standing next to Marc Brickman when that happened… If I remember correctly, only 1/3rd of the first section collapsed into the pit, taking out a few stage monitors, but the band did close with "On Broadway". At the end of the concert, I went to the green room for our "idiot sweep" and picked up the two setlists that were left on the couch…. Each band member got a sheet, torn from a looseleaf book, and wrote the setlist in their own handwriting (so they could read it).
Bummer (in response to Joe Kivak leaving to soon…) Lawrence Kirsch told me it was the only time Bruce and the Band ever played 'On Broadway' live. And it was thrown in as an encore idea back in the dressing room, before the show…….. so being the tight band they were at the time, they may have just winged it. I know that in the 2+ years I worked with them, I never heard it at a concert, rehearsal or sound check….

Mike Batlan

Back then there was no actual planned ‘tour’. Everything was sort of on the fly. Mike Appel would just get gigs even as we traveled around. Gigs like Liberty Hall (Houston) and others were booked from Appel’s hotel room while were doing a show in New Orleans or Atlanta or Nashville. More than once I would be in Appel’s hotel room asking where we were going “next” and he’d just say “I’m working on it”. So Appel sometimes didn’t know what we were going to—what the actual venue was. Sometimes we didn’t know how many shows. Liberty Hall was one of them. It was kind of a very cool place—part concert hall—part nightclub with tables. We were originally only supposed to be there for one show but things were (always) “flexible”. We ended up there for about four nights simply because the reception for Bruce was good and we had no real plan.

So anyway, we’re in Texas and Appel books a show in Dallas. I think it was supposed to be after the Armadillo World Headquarters shows. Jeff Hall and myself manage to find this place. It was a rusted out corrugated tin building out on the prairie—there was nothing but prairie—just empty prairie way outside of Dallas. Jeff and I just looked at each and were like—'this doesn’t look good’. We go inside and it’s a BOXING RING. There are no people there for sound—or lights. The only thing we see are the boxing announcer horns above the ring and the building’s hanging flood lights and the seating was just benches on all four sides. The place smelled of sweat and urine and was filthy. Jeff and I really have doubts about unloading the band gear—and we had no idea which way to face the gear for any sort of show. So we start looking for someone to talk to. There were some locker rooms and we finally found an office—and inside the office was the “promoter”—who was busy cooking drugs (heroin) in a spoon. Yeah—that was a shocker even to us. So we ask him if he knows about the show and this guy says “I’m the promoter—but I need a little privacy—I’ll be with you in a little while”.

Jeff and I both decided we weren’t unloading any band gear.

And shortly after that, Appel arrives—followed by the band (in another station wagon). We tell Appel what the story is and he decides to take a look. Meanwhile Bruce gets out of the wagon takes a look at this decrepit corrugated tin building surrounded by deserted prairie and says “I’m not playing here”
And that was it—decision made.

We went back towards the actual city of Dallas to some rooms (Holiday Inn I think) and Appel got on the phone to find us another gig in Dallas. He did. It was some sort of strip club and we actually did do a show there to a massive crowd of about 5 strippers and a few drunks at the bar and maybe about 8 or 10 other people (the strippers loved the show) . But it was still a lot nicer than the ‘boxing ring’.

Barry Sulkin I was the VP of the concert committee PK German at the time, in charge of ticket sales and venue. I greeted the tour manager and hung out on the bus behind the gym in the afternoon before the show, and Bruce came in and joined us for a while. There were no seats as I recall, and everyone sat on the floor. No opening act. I heard Lou Rawles was in the audience. He took us all by surprise - best show of the year.

Rick Bohs Another college auditorium show that I went to. This time with my wife at the time. I do remember Bruce coming out to yell at the crowd about the booing for the opening solo singer. Quote “Shut the Fuck up or I’m not gonna play!” Most memorable moment came during “Rosalita” when a giant disco ball dropped from the ceiling and everyone was dancing and screaming!

JerseyJoe On December 14, 1974 I attended a Billy Joel concert at Rutgers University (ticket price $4.75). This concert was held in the small gymnasium which was affectionately nicknamed "The Barn". Just before the concert began my friends and myself decided to walk over to the men's locker room that Billy was using as a dressing room to try and snap a few pictures as he emerged to go onstage. The quickest way to get there was to walk underneath the bleachers that were on the side of the gym. I remember seeing the outline of a scruffy guy sitting huddled up with his back against the wall under the bleachers. I thought it quite odd and that perhaps this guy must be either stoned or drunk since the show was about to begin in minutes and here he was sitting with his back up against the wall in the darkness. During the excellent show Billy paused and dedicated the song "The Entertainer" to his friend and fellow Columbia Recording Artist in the audience - BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN. You could see the Bruce fans scanning the audience looking for that beanie that he used to wear. No luck. For the third encore Billy invited Bruce onstage to perform an impromptu version of "Twist & Shout". I can remember the feeling of seeing these two performers together on stage knowing that they were both destined to become superstars. (It did not strike me until the next day that the scruffy guy huddled in the shadows under the bleachers; that I was inches away from me was in fact Bruce who was trying to keep low key).
John W. Mellor I was there that night and while few in University Park or State College PA knew the Band well, after the show everyone knew you were going to be great.

Rich Engler I had been hearing about this act, Bruce Springsteen from Asbury Park, N.J. who was supposed to be the next big thing. John Kostick, a rep from CBS Records, played me an advance copy of "Born To Run", and it was obvious that it was going to be a huge hit. I booked a show with Bruce at the Syria Mosque in early 1975, and in no time we had a sellout. The concert was fabulous; everything I had heard about Bruce as a performer was true. He commanded the stage and drove the fans into a frenzy. They were singing along to even the most obscure Springsteen songs, and it was obvious a star was being born. Every now and then, an act comes along that just has it all. Bruce was one of those. John Kostick asked if Cindy and I would like to join him and Bruce for a bite to eat after the concert. They were headed to Cleveland for another show. I called Carmassi's, an Italian restaurant we went to on occasion, to make sure it was going to be open late. The owner, Sonny Carmassi, assured me we could dine there. When the four of us arrived, the door was locked. I knocked, Sonny came out, looked at us, and pulled me inside the restaurant. "Listen Rich, I can let the three of you in but not that other guy. He's not dressed properly." Bruce was wearing a wife beater, jeans, and sandals. "What do you mean? Do you know who that is? That's Bruce Springsteen!" "Who's Bruce Springsteen? I don't care who he is, he can't come in the restaurant dressed like that." After much pleading, Sonny let us in. I told him that after we ate he should frame Bruce's place setting, put it on the wall and people would come in just to look at it. Sonny didn't believe that Bruce would be a superstar, however, we were able to have dinner. The waiter came and took our orders. Bruce had the most unusual order…corn on the cob for dinner and then later, apple pie. Shortly after that, Bruce's picture was on the cover of Newsweek and Time magazines. I called Sonny to be sure he kept the place setting, but he hadn't. He never realized how big a star had dined in his restaurant. We still laugh about it today.
Behind the Stage Door: A Promoter's Life Behind The Scenes
Bill Lurye I was at this show, and have some pictures. I was just a few rows back and they allowed me to bring my 35 mm camera. He opened with Incident - Suki at center stage. Rosalita, later, I honestly can't say I remember others, but I'd bet it was close to the Penn State and Bryn Mawr shows. And yes, Richie Havens opened, and was way late due to his flight being delayed.

Paul Johnson I recall the Freaky Friar. And the Freaky Friar was not alone. There were three or four guys dressed in Friar outfits, one in white and the others in brown. At least one had a Friar Tuck haircut. During one of the songs toward the end of the show, one of the friars jumped on stage and gave Bruce his girth rope. The other guy Bruce mentions was a 'civilian' that, in a fit of euphoria, jumped up on stage and shook Bruce's hand.
That wasn't the last sighting of the friars, who I also spotted at the final show of the spring two nights later. As we stood on the [D.A.R. Constitution] Hall steps waiting for the soundcheck to be completed, I turned and saw the friars again. Kind of creepy… but no reoccurrence of the Painters Mill episode.

Ross Crumlish I was in attendance - sitting up on the side, near the top of the gym. I attended with my high school girlfriend. A very high energy show (of course) - I have a vague memory of Bruce climbing up and standing on the top of the piano during “Rosalita” and leaping off at the climactic moment. Drove up with my girlfriend (now my life partner) from Philadelphia for the show. And, yes, many of the floor chairs in the gym were in ruins after the show! When I got back to school in Washington DC that fall, one of my friends (who grew up in Reading, PA) had this poster (See News/Memorabilia-tab), and had also attended the concert. When we graduated, he gave me this as a going away/graduation present. He is still in my life almost 50 years later as one of my best friends, and we still talk about this show! The girlfriend and I went our separate ways, and then, almost 40 years later, we reunited and are now partners! I gave her this poster as a birthday present a few years ago, and it hangs in her office at work.
Michael I saw Springsteen in Austin on Sept 12, 1975. I can confirm that his last encore was "I Fought the Law". It was great.

Wayne Eberhart I DID see BRUCE when he first hit Seattle in November of 1975………he was on the cover of Newsweek and TIME that week as well. Bought tickets ahead of time……….second ROW in a 2,000 seat theater the PARAMOUNT in Seattle………….the ticket? with tax……………….5 dollars. 2nd row ! good GOD…………sold the stub on ebay a few years back for over 50 dollars. I was 20. I just remember when he was doing BORN TO RUN I had !!!!!!!! to go pee……so had to excuse myself and walk past a dozen people to get to the aisle and the can………..I got back before he was done and could hear the music the whole time even away from hall. I tell ya……I remember well Clarence wailing out the opening number……..JUNGLELAND. I can tell you for a fact he opened with JUNGLELAND……..so if you have that you have the first song…. I remember 10th ave freeze out pretty sure……..he really didn't have much out yet……Born to Run was basically new then. he DID play that one for sure………I told you my memory of that one……..the incredible thing was that even though I was in the second row, the music just compelled us to stand up it was that good ! I was THINKING !!! Thunder Road……..that was it………it starts out slow and builds and that is what he opened with………for sure.
Pat Panuco Hello! I am a big Bruce Springsteen fan, having seen him perform at least 6 or 7 times in the 70s and 80s. I recently Googled “How much is a 1975 Bruce Springsteen Paramount NW Concert poster worth” and came across the entry for that concert on the Brucebase Wiki. I had to laugh at the comment regarding “a partial audience recording that cuts in during “Backstreets’”… because I was there and helped make that recording! Back in 1975, I had a military buddy (Stan Gutoski (RIP)), who had an extra ticket and wanted to know if I would help him record the show. We had heard of Bruce and read all the hype, but we still only knew that he had written “Blinded by the Light” and we had heard “Born to Run” on the radio. We wanted to see what he was all about! He and I had recorded many rock concerts prior to this show, using a reel-to-reel recorder and a Nacamichi mic, but this night my friend had just gotten an new Sony Cassette Deck and wanted to use it. We got to the Paramount early and stood in line… I remember only 10 people ahead of us… and we were able to get front row seats. However, we were pushed back 4 rows because the front was reserved for the press. The seats we ended up with at the balcony were still great, with a bank of speakers directly in front of us. Unfortunately, we weren’t familiar with the record and volume controls on the new Sony deck. The show started and we began recording. When it was time to put in a new cassette (we only used 1 side when recording to allow for time tracking) we went to swap tapes and realized that we hadn’t taken the original off pause! We always said there was a million ways to screw up a recording! So, unfortunately, we missed the first half of the show, and only started recording midway through “Backstreets.”

Dennis Lockard About all this talk about It's My Life being first played at C.W. Post…… I will swear on my stack of boots that it was first played at Bucknell two nights earlier. I remember my buddies discussing it afterwards, saying what a great song it was, one saying "what a great opening couplet: 'it's a hard world to get a break in, all the good things have been taken…' None of us had heard the song and did research over the next week to find out it was an Animals song. Now, I can't prove it was played that night. But I didn't see him again until Penn State the following April….and I KNOW I heard it played live once. That's my story and I know it's true.

Briar Duckworth In the Gym with the Bleechers pulled out! Pre xmas show. 1st show in TO. Fab.
John Zizzo Home from university for Xmas and buddies say we have to see this 'guy' who we didn't know a lot about - small gym small crowd …. Amazing !! Still have the ticket stub $7.50 …. Lol !!

Greg Thompson This was my first Springsteen show and my first trip into Atlanta by myself (I was 18). This unfortunately led to me and my buddies getting lost and missing the first of the show. A guy sitting behind us told us he had opened with Night. After getting settled in our seats Bruce began the familiar harmonica intro to Thunder Road. A high energy version followed and this led right into Born to Run. Since all this happened almost 30 years ago now I can't remember the order in which he played everything but he for sure played It's Hard to be a Saint in the City (a great guitar battle between him and Miami Steve), Blinded by the Light (he looked over the album cover before starting and said "OK,I got it".), Backstreets, Jungleland, an early version of Frankie (playing a wooden block with a drum stick for percussion), Sandy (the angels on their Harleys version) and Rosalita. He did both the Detroit Medley and Quarter to Three for encores and ended the night on his knees screaming, "I'm just a prisoner … of rock & roll!" I've never been the same & wouldn't want it any other way.

Ed Beddingfield Detroit Medley was played at this show……… My first of 57 shows.
Scott Diffee The show lasted about 3.5 hours .. long, and great. This was a very high energy show that I will certainly never forget. Bruce and the band were in excellent form and looked they were having more fun than the audience .. and the audience was ecstatic. This was one of the few shows where the entire Born To Run album was performed. This was my first time seeing Bruce and still ranks as one of the best shows I have ever seen by anyone and I've seen many many shows. The power of Bruce and this band during that time was huge. The energy was unmatched, the crowd was in a constant buzz and was into every note and every run across the stage, jumps from the piano, etc… An unforgettable night for all those in attendance for sure .. WOW
'Unknown' I recollect "It's My Life" and that I distinctly remember looking down the row of people and seeing that every single one of them had their mouths open (as did I) in stunned silence, mesmerized by the story and the music. It was thrilling.

Daniel The concert was scheduled for around 7:00pm…folks started lining up outside at about 4:30pm. By 7:00pm I'd estimate there were over a thousand people outside and the doors were still shut. At about 7:10 there was commotion up front and I remember seeing one of the doors get literally torn from the hinges - and these were big, heavy wood doors! The next minutes were a blur, seeing one girl getting pushed into the glass marque-poster cases, seeing another girl who fainted getting passed overhead…the mad rush to get a good seat.
Bob Suddenly the doors opened and we were pushed in so I raced to the front and got two seats. I remember the show was a little too loud in the front row, but it was amazing. The night before the show Springsteen went to my favorite bar (Swanky's) and hung out. I didn't go that night. I saw his picture in the paper the next morning standing where I usually went to drink.
Gary Obloy When the show was announced, some thought it was an April Fools joke. Of course, it wasn't. Bruce opened the show with "Night" from the Born to Run album and played all of the album tracks during the show. It was Bruce's second stop at OU. The first was in the spring of 1972 at OU's Convocation Center. He was part of a music festival that included the Eagles, the James Gang, Blood, Sweat and Tears and others.

John Goodin My seat was third or fourth-row center but we stood all night. My journal entry doesn't have a list but it mentions a long story intro to "It's My Life", a solo piano version of "For You" that began the second encore followed by a Mitch Ryder medley and "Raise Your Hand" (which I'd never heard before). My journal entry says: "Bruce's last words: I'm just a prisoner… of rock'n'roll!".
Kevin We sat near the back, best concert, standing ovation every song, great venue. So quiet you could hear everything. Lighting awesome, only cheers were few guys yelling Bruce…. It was a magical night. Jungleland gave me chills… Have seen them twice since, never will compare to that night… Thanks Bruce, E street, they called him… Miami Steve Van Zandt back then.

Mike Combes This was my first Bruce concert ever and it is a concert experience I will never forget. The first time I had ever heard a Springsteen song was the night before when a guy in my dorm let me borrow Born to Run. I was not initially impressed, but still decided to go to the show. The songs that didn't mean anything to me on the record came to life during his live performance. I had never seen a performer connect with the audience like this before. I was a Bruce fan forever. My favorite song of the night was actually a cover of the Animals "It's My Life". Bruce the storyteller told of playing his guitar in his bedroom as his father yelled at him to keep the noise down. Interesting tidbit, I had a friend who was an usher for the show and he was there during the soundcheck and Bruce played "Incident on 57th Street".
Paula I'll just never forget the night I saw Bruce. He was all over the stage, just having a great time. So was I for that matter. Nobody is better in concert than Bruce!
'Tapeboy' This was my third time seeing Bruce and my first time successfully getting my recorder into the show. It is arguably my best recording set up as well: the Sony 153SD cassette deck and Advent dynamic stereo mics. I also got my camera and a couple of lenses in…ahh…those were the days. MSU Auditorium was a gymnasium-type place with a U-shaped, single-level balcony surrounding the seats set up on the floor, where we were in the 11th row. This show featured all of 'Born To Run' in an era before full-album shows. It was also the first time I'd heard Bruce play "It's My Life", "Raise Your Hand", and the brand new "Frankie", which featured Bruce on cowbell and pointed in a songwriting direction away from the sound of 'Born To Run'. "It's My Life" was stunning, virtually unrecognizable until the chorus, and prompting a standing ovation midway through the song as the band completed the first chorus. Despite Bruce saying on the 2016 River tour that "Independence Day" was his first song about fathers and sons (and what about "Adam Raised A Cain"?), clearly the spoken beginning of "It's My Life" is where he first visited this theme. We left the show knowing we'd seen a great one, and thinking that a new album must be just around the corner; it was unimaginable that 'Darkness' was still over 2 years away!

David Vallieres I was at the Colgate concert. I lived in Utica (near Hamilton), was just 18 and loved Bruce's songs… it was an incredible performance. I can't remember how many encores he came back for but is at least 10… he just coming back and back. One of the best concerts I ever saw.
Don Freedman My first. Made all the more incredible by comparison because I had see the anemic Peter Frampton show two days earlier at which he more or less replicated his Frampton Comes Alive disc. While Bruce blew the roof off the hockey rink at Colgate. Would give anything to relive that cold night.
Lin Watt Doyle My first Springsteen concert. I was a freshman at Colgate which is in Hamilton, NY, a small and very remote town in upstate NY. He had been on the covers of Time and Newsweek the previous fall so for him to actually come to Hamilton, NY was HUGE. Pretty much everyone knew who he was by April of 1976 but I had arrived in the fall of 1975 as a freshman with 2 of his albums! (I grew up in NJ). I thought I was pretty hot stuff. And I've seen him maybe 7 or 8 times over the years, most recently at The Wrecking Ball tour at Fenway Park on 8/15/2012. And even though I was 55, it was as if I was still an 18-year-old Colgate Freshman.
Paul Leonard A great show! My second Bruce show, with great versions of Incident on 57th Street and Sandy. At one point later in the show, Bruce's Telecaster guitar wasn't working and he had to borrow one of Miami Steve's Stratocasters. Bruce said "Steve, this guitar stinks!" and Steve said "That's why I don't use it."
Vicky Ludwig I was at the Colgate show. Really small venue. I thought he was kind of AM radio, but the show was amazing and I went out and bought his albums.
'Rootboy' Benefit concert arranged by John Hammond, Sr. who Bruce owed a favor. Maybe 700 people… mostly students who had barely heard of Bruce.

Tim Curley I can’t swear to the date, but fits my college years in western pa and there appears to be only one Johnstown concert. We definitely saw him in Johnstown. The most memorable song in my listening was a cover of the Animals; "We Gotta Get Out of this Place". After the initial big hit straight ahead full blast series. Every one is spent The band goes silent. Then Bruce starts this long rambling talk, barely audible, about how his dad didn’t understand him, then he walks out the door, the screen door slams and he said all he could say was then screaming "We Gotta Get out of this Place" Animals cover. The arena exploded. I’m shocked no one mentions. The reaction was louder & more visceral than to his hit songs.

Mike We thought the show had ended after the second encore. We were outside when we heard the crowd go wild. We ran back inside and found the band back on stage, plugging in, with all the house lights on. They must have played "Twist And Shout" for ten minutes. When they finished, they appeared ready to do another number when one of the ladies who ushered the Mosque walked up behind Bruce, tapped him on the shoulder and motioned with her finger "no more". It was a perfect comic ending, as Bruce acted frightened and ran off stage with the others while this 60-year old meanie stood there with her hands on her broad hips.

Tom Ucko My first Bruce show. Went not really knowing what to expect and was not a big fan going in. The concert absolutely blew me away. I felt an emotional connection with the songs about growing up and about not being a certain way just because society says you should. Was especially struck by Frankie and It's My Life - the Animals cover. Awesome show. Wish there was a boot!

Mike I was near the stage and actually patted Bruce on the back when he jumped from the stage and wandered among the audience as he played his guitar. It will always be the best concert I've ever seen because of the incredible energy level, as well as the fantastic music and performance by the band.

Bob Weaver The VA Tech Vawter Hall first floor took turns camping out for 2 weeks for front row seats. We got them, first few center rows and after the concert started, people jumped in the orchestra pit. I was part of the camp out and I'd be damned if I wasn't going to be up front! So I jumped up and had my hands on the stage in front of the Big Man for the whole concert. It was the best concert I had ever been to, and none since has been better. Bruce came out in the crowd, not sure what song it was. It was all just a great time, never will be another like it!
Jeff Hilton I was there with 30 or so friends from Roanoke College. After Sandy the band left the stage. They came back and played their 3 to 4 Song Detroit Medley. They left the stage again. About half the audience left. The rest of us just kept screaming from more. They came out and played Twist and Shout.
Robert Glascock I was sixteen years old, and could have easily been a stand-in for "Dazed and Confused". I took a bus from South Boston, VA. because there weren't too many Bruce fans around town! After witnessing many Ted Nugent, Bad Co., Aerosmith gigs this show was a revelation for a shit-kicker like me. I can remember leaving the hall prior to the last encore and walking across the large drill field back to my brothers dorm! As we were walking and excitedly talking about what we had just witnessed, a large roar came up from the few people still remaining at the hall! We had to haul ass back to witness Bruce on top of the keyboards instructing the roadies to prepare for another encore!!! I'm sure this sight is not unusual for early Bruce fans, but for me it was truly a breath of fresh air after the excesses and cattle-like jam festivals of the 70's! Needless to say the encore was fantastic and I walked back across the drill field , exhausted , thrilled, and musically satisfied!!!

Jim I was there. Initially my reason for going was to go on a double date. The dates never materialized! We arrived really early and went to the gym to hang out. Once there, a guy who identified himself as the tour manager for Bruce asked me and my friend if we would go out and buy some ice and drinks for them to use back stage. He handed us $500 (which back then was a huge amount of money) and we headed to a convenience store in Boone. When we returned he asked if we had tickets, we said yes and he asked if we would like to sit up front. It was then that we saw Bruce - he was in a corner of the gym by himself practicing on the guitar. The concert was incredible and of course from then on I was hooked as a Bruce fan. Since then my kids have also been introduced to his music and tonight I am off to DC to see him with my youngest son.
Michael Harris It was April 24 1976, I remember I went with my roommate and his girlfriend. The girl I was dating didn't want to go. She said she would stay at the apartment and watch TV (shouda known there was something wrong with that girl right off). We had heard the album but hadn't seen Bruce live. If you're a Booner of the '76 era you know the gym was a fairly small venue. We were able to get right down on the floor not far from the stage. His performance was incredible. We spent the next 3 hrs. jumping up and down, pumping our fist, singings chorus to some of the songs. When we got back to the apartment my girlfriend wanted to know if we were on drugs. We said, "Yes, it's called Springsteen, and it's a high like you've never experienced in your life. Ever since then I've been hooked, and I've made it a generational experience. My little boy came running out of his first Springsteen concert yelling, "BTR baby, BTR." As Clarence has said many times before, "This could be the beginning of something big".
Tom Harrisburg I was with a bunch of PA/NJ kids that came up from Wake Forest. Was my second Bruce show and very memorable - first saw Bruce at Kutztown State in '75. We kept clapping at the end - they came out for two additional encores AFTER the house lights were on. Good Golly/Blue Shoes - 3 hours, plus and only a few hundred die-hards at the end. Crowd had begged for Born to Run - the only song most of the locals knew - we laughed about that. I am writing this just after Clarence's passing - it's both comforting and sad to reminisce. Thanks for the space.

Jenny Folks dancing in the aisles during the show were shutdown by security. This elicited boos from the audience, and provoked Bruce to make sarcastic comments about the staff from the stage.
Joel The entire upper level of seating, all the way around the inside of the auditorium was curtained off. On the main floor there were two separate sections for seating. There were so few people there that only a few rows in the second section were used. The place really looked empty because it was. I was sitting stage left in the opera section, about four rows from the stage. The opera seating was only a few feet above the main floor level. When the band came out and started the first song, "Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out", I remember the stunned looks on everyone's faces just below me in the audience. I won't forget that I could see my brother sitting in the aisle directly in front of me about ten people away on the main floor. He was just as shocked as everyone else. It was electrifying.
Steve Bruce's road crew came out before the start of the show and nailed a piece of plywood from the edge of the stage over the top of the security barricades. Bruce jumped off the stage and played in the crowd a number of times. The show still ranks as one of my all-time favorite concerts.

Tom Herrod This was my first time to see Bruce and the guys and I can only say that at that time there was no way to be prepared for just what it is these guys did and have continued doing for so long….. they came out in their cool suits, everybody wearing shades, and launched into "night" I knew it was gonna be a ride….. great rapport with the audience, super energy, high drama and great joy, every emotion imaginable throughout the show….. I have never heard any thing more intense than the performance of "hard to be a saint in the city"….. Bruce and Steve just kept kickin' it farther out into the whoa zone….. this was one of those things you didn't know you were waiting for till you were there…..
Elaine Attendance was very sparse. We sat in the fourth or fifth row and there was no one behind us, I think about 200-300. But Bruce played for two hours and seemed to give it maximum effort.

Unknown Us commoners had to sit in the last five or six rows as the cadets, decked out in dress whites, had all of the rest of the theater. The sound was amazing. The big crescendos of "Growin' Up" seemed to move through us from left to right. I mentioned that to Bruce at the Stone Pony before Southside's May 30 radio broadcast and he said that Eisenhower Hall was supposed to be one of the best acoustic theaters in the country. I believe it.
Allem Whitwood The day after, my brother Jim and I had beers with Clarence at Middleton's Tavern outside, while he waited for his table on the inside.

Wendy I remember this night - Asbury was still Asbury - the bars, the circuit, the boardwalk and rides. I was at a show at the Fastlane and then went walking, with my friends, to the Stone Pony. Well, we heard some music and it wasn't recorded music! So we went in and there was Bruce - What a night - the Spirit of '76 and Bruce and the band - truly memorable. The other thing I won't forget is that my friend had the battery stolen out of her car that night!

Eddie Manion This gig was during a CBS (Epic Records) Convention at The Beverly Wiltshire Hotel Hollywood, CA with the original Miami Horns Carlo Novi, Tony Pallagrosi, and myself. "We had to go on stage before The Jackson 5 with Michael Jackson. They were impeccable, We weren't bad ourselves but they were great! Bruce also guested during this set. I was 25 years old."

Ken Walling I was 14yrs. old. It was my first rock concert. What a way to start. I was from Freehold so it meant that much more to me and still does to this day. Thinking back on that night now all these years, 29, later what I remember most was when he walked on stage. He wore a dark suit. I expected leather. The rush I felt was incredible. Little Steven, who was Miami Steve then, standing to his left in an all orange suit and hat. Bruce told stories about our hometown and rocked the shit out of the place.
Al Rodack I believe Bruce did 10 shows over 7 days at the theatre. Show was only about 90 minutes. He had Southside Johnny's horn section out for several songs. He went into the audience twice.

Unknown So we sit patiently waiting for the band, with no idea what is about to hit us. After a seemingly endless wait, the lights dim and the band comes out and Bam! they burst into "Night" - such a powerhouse version that I can still feel the buzz from it when I think about it. That song is never mentioned as one of the great Springsteen tunes, but since that time, I've always regarded it as one of his finest. I've been a huge rock music fan for all of my life - since those days, I've been a music critic and written hundreds of articles and thousands of reviews and have bought well over ten thousand records and CDs. I've played in my own band, recorded multiple CDs, and run an independent record label, and after all this, I still think of that show as the point where I first saw something that I've only seen a handful of other times: what real rock and roll is.

Peggy Hannan I remember Bruce eating M&M's while they did the sound check. I bought 3rd row seats and didn't realize there was no opening act, I was going to work and then change clothes for the show. I have pictures, this is when the band dressed up in suits Little Steven in Red, Clarence in white. They blew the roof off!

Ralph So, it's been thirty years for me since my first Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band event at Rutgers. I wrote a review a few years back on Greasylake.org and said that this night "lit the fuse". Little did I know that Bruce would write a song called "The Fuse" as few years later. After 106 shows, the fuse is still buring brightly in my life. This show at Rutgers was a perfect show. Bruce and his 'blood brothers' making the audience laugh, cry and beg for more. I was surrounded by friends that I would know forever - and still do some thirty years later. Wow. I have a lot of new friends that are Bruce friends, and that has enriched my life to no end. That night. What a night. The song "Night" opened the show - as it usually did on that tour. Thereafter, a Best of Bruce cornucopia of songs that we would forever love. How could we go wrong? It was the time of our life. Wow! Rap
Ralph This was my first of, to date, 100 Bruce shows. This lit the fuse! We did not know what we would have for the rest of our lives! A great night - the beginning of everything. Sixteen songs that seemed like magic.

Howard Brayer Second time I saw Bruce - the first was at the same school in 1974. This time there was a lottery for tickets as the theater held only about 900 people. I got first row seats! I remember the show was very exciting, but can't remember any particulars now that it is 33 years later.
John Hillock Fifth row center, with Donna R./Born to Run had just launched Bruce and the band into the stratosphere … Rosalita was a spiritual experience. A truly great memory.. 31 yrs later bringing my 19 yr old daughter to MSG on 10/19/07 for more — thx Bruce

Eric Thiessen Mark is right - there were more tunes played that night than what you have listed. We were allowed to stand in the center aisle in the front row as our seats were at the right side end of the front row so when Bruce jumped off the stage into the crowd he landed next to us… was amazed at how short he was considering how large his presence is on stage…
Jay Edwin The band stayed at the Strawberry Banks Motor Inn in Hampton after the show. We were tipped to the location by Clarence's aunt, who taught at a friend's high school in Chesapeake. That's where I got the autograph. Also notice the fact the name on the ticket is misspelled as "Springstein".
Mark Bintliff I was at this show and while I don't remember every single detail I know that the Motor City Medley with "Devil with a Blue Dress" and "CC Rider" were in the set list. I can't say I know of any others that have been omitted.
Unknown We all camped out for two days and nights creating our own little world with two dozen others on the William & Mary Hall steps, then in the foyer, to get front and center tickets. We had proxies stand in for us while we went to (some) classes. The night of the concert was totally worth it when Bruce came right down into the audience to us and sang "Jungleland" and joined us in an arm-in-arm group dance.
Courtesy of Richmond Times-Dispatch website.

Larry This was my first Bruce show and i was hooked for life…. have seen him about 80 times in the next 32 years…. what i remember most is the miami horns during Tenth Ave freezeout….had never heard anything so powerful in my life… blew me away…. I was with my best friend and we were about 20 rows back…. we spent the rest of our junior year in college drivin around in my car listening to whatever bootlegs we could get our hands on… still love him the same till today.

Greg Arnold This was a birthday show for me. Had @ 10 tickets for the show for friends and family (old g/f worked for Ticketron, as it was called then). Anyway was sitting right on the aisle, 3rd row, and in the middle of the show, who's kneeling next to me in the aisle but Patti Smith. Next thing I know she's on stage, and i swear they sung "Because the Night". Or maybe I did a bit too much celebrating before the show at McSorley's. Great night! Had tickets to all 6 shows, nothing worse than 3rd row… thank you Denise!!!

'JerseyGirl' This was the night of the bomb scare. They evacuated the theater, we waited in the streets while they check the place (police, fire dept, dogs, etc) and then they let us back in to finish the show. What a memory!

Didi D'Errico Bruce came to our house for dinner and Carl signed a copy of "It's My Life" sheet music to him. They both played the song together, Bruce on guitar and Carl on piano, I did back up vocals… sorry I did not put the tape deck on… They were great together!
Maluk Popeye It's my life was a song I used to blast when my parent gave me shit. When he played it, I lost my mind and felt it was a sign from God or devil. I'll never forget it. Seminal moment.

Daniel Scotti I was born and raised in Northern NJ and would spend my summers in Long Branch. It was Labor Day weekend and there was a benefit concert at the Stone Pony for Bob Campanell of the Cahoots, who I think had cancer. The word was that Bruce was home and might make an appearance. My cousin and I went and sat at the bar. Sure enough towards the end of the evening, Bruce and Clarence were announced and got up from the table where they were sitting and joined the band on stage for the final set. I have no idea what band was playing because all that I cared about was seeing Bruce up close and personal. I am pretty sure it was September of 1974 and Labor Day was September 2nd. The whole thing was that "It was Labor Day Weekend and Bruce was around". It could have been 1973 or 1975 but I have always said 1974.

Robert Hamburger My first time hearing Bruce, but certainly not the last. At the time I had never heard of him. A friend INSISTED that we get tickets and go see him at Red Rocks, and if I wasn’t blown away, he would pay me back my money. Coincidentally, my friend’s name was Bruce and he was from NJ! Well, if you’ve never been to Red Rocks, put it on your bucket list. I regard it as the greatest concert venue in the world, and just visiting the park and taking in the surroundings makes for a magnificent experience. The band doesn’t even need to show up for it to be a great day! Bands routinely comment that performing at Red Rocks is on their bucket list. So, of course I said yes. And was blown away and became a lifetime convert on the spot. Instantly my favorite performer, and this against the backdrop of living in SoCal in my late teens and seeing Jimi, Janis, Jim, Jerry and all the rest live in small venues. But Bruce of course was on another level. Red Rocks holds about 12,000 and it was not a sold out show, maybe 7 or 8 thousand that day. Didn’t matter, folks went nuts. Kept pulling the band out for extra encores (just like everywhere), and finally at the very end he does I Fought The Law. Prefaced it by saying they had only learned it that morning… and then when we screamed for more, he laughed and said “We don’t know any more songs!” And that was that.

Dee Lippingwell I was forced to crouch between the seats to get Clarence Clemons, Bruce and Steve VanZant in action. Sitting with CBS execs made the task even more difficult but 16 frames later I knew I had a great shot!

Bornintime At 16 years old back in 1978 Darkness On The Edge Of Town was the first serious album I ever bought. Up to then I was buying Aerosmith, Kansas, Rush and the like, didn't own a thing (yet) by Bob, Bruce, Van, Neil etc. Back in those days we all listened to the radio because it was fresh and exciting. WPLJ in New York City was my station. They started playing 4 songs from Darkness constantly (as well as broadcasting the Cleveland '78 show which I taped on my radio shack 8-track stereo - still have the tapes). Carol Miller, an amazing DJ at WPLJ, seemed to have a major crush on Bruce.

Unknown We were at the Agora on August 31. We had tried desperately to get tickets for Bruce that night at the Coliseum but it got sold out. The Agora gig was actually a Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes gig that started about three hours late because, as Southside stated, they had to wait for their lead guitarist (Miami Steve) to get done with another gig across town. Bruce joined the band in the second set and they rocked into the wee hours of the night, neither the band nor the crowd wanted to leave… it was about 4am when we finally got home (with little, or no voice). Great intimate concert with Bruce and Southside.

John A. Ruckstaetter My first Bruce concert was 9-9-78 at Notre Dame's ACC. The description doesn't tell it all. After the concert "ended" the lights came up, the place emptied and the stage was stripped down to just a mic stand and 1 speaker. There were about 12 of us left in the building, 6 guys, 6 girls. The Andy Frain ushers started yelling at us to leave. We started chanting BRUUUUUCE. The ushers came down to the front row where we had moved to and…Bruce came out on stage, plugged in his guitar and played 3-4 songs, just for the 12 of us and a few security guards. I swear they were songs we didn't know, had never heard, but were soon thereafter, on The River, songs like Point Blank, Independence Day come to mind. Can't remember the other 2. My friend and I told everybody about it… nobody believed us. You might not either, but I don't care, because I lived it.

Mike Rogers This was my very first Springsteen show. I recall that setlist as well. I also recall the part of the show when Bruce collapsed, faking exhaustion. EMT's came on stage and took him off. I sure didn't know he was faking it, because just like everything Bruce does seems so real. He returned and my life has never been the same, some 40+ years and 36 shows later. We also got to see the sound check.

Dave L. This was my first Bruce and the E Street band experience. My buddy and I had gotten tickets the day they went on sale on our lunch break. We got 16 front row seat tickets. We had to wait three months because the original date of Mid may had been cancelled and rescheduled. It was definitely worth the wait. Myself and 15 other buddies walked to our front row seats at about 5 minutes before showtime like we were the mayors of the city.
